Асоева Ашурби проживает в городе Яван.Имеет средне-специальное образование . Работает медсестрой в поликлинике города Яван. Кроме того она занимается торговлей молока . Скупает у соседей и вывозит в центр города для реализации. Хочет купить дойнукю корову , чтобы получать свое домашнее молоко. Это будет приносить больший доход для ее семьи. Для того , чтобы купить корову ей нужен кредит. Получив его она сможет погашать его в течении 6 месяцев. Ашурби 35 лет , у нее 2 детей . Муж умер и поэтому вся ответственность за обеспечение семьи лежит на ней. Но она не унывает и живет с детьми дружно и весело.

loans.use: Purchase of a milk cow

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr:
Mr S. is a carpenter who has been practicing the trade for over 20 years. He is married but does not yet have any children. He usually takes out loans to buy wood to make furniture which he then sells to his customers. With this loan he wants to increase his wood supplies before the rainy season sets in.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

mr S. est un menuisier qui exerce cette profession depuis une vingtaine d'année .il est marié mais n'a pas encore d'enfant.il a l'habitude de prendre des crédits pour acheter du bois dans le but de fabriquer des meubles et les revendre à ses clients .avec ce pret il veut renforcer son stock de bois avant l'installation de l'hivernage.

loans.use: To buy wood to make furniture

loans.name: Dickson

texts.en:
Dickson is a 30-year-old single man who lives in Nyalenda in Kisumu. He is the proprietor of several businesses. One of his businesses supplies milk and bread to several outlets. He also keeps poultry which produce eggs for sale locally. Dickson initiated his businesses between the years 2006 and 2007. He requires an additional credit amounting to US $600 to help him buy more milk and bread to supply his top clients.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Purchase more milk and bread

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey N. sells coal door-to-door in Khnach Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Because this business is going well, Mrs. N. is requesting a loan to buy a cart to transport her coal.

Mrs. N. is a 50-year-old widow with a child who is in high school. Previously, she obtained a loan to buy coal to resell in the village, and she has fully repaid the loan.

loans.use: Buy a cart to transport the coal when selling door-to-door

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Nguyen Thi L. is 44 years old. She joined TYM in 2004 to borrow loans to raise chickens. As she can take advantage of available chicken-feed at home, her family's chicken raising business has been very effective with an average income of VND 2.5 million. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 10 million to buy more breeding chickens and pigs and animal-feed to expand her raising business and generate more income for the family.
texts.en:
Note: the original description is in English.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy sows and chickens

loans.name: Palmira

texts.es:
La señora Palmira pertenece al Grupo de Crédito Mientras Tanto “Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria” y vive en la Región y Provincia San Martín, distrito de Tarapoto. Se dedica a la venta de comida tipo menú y su negocio está ubicado en su casa en el Jr. Elías Aguirre Nº 203, lugar donde espera a sus clientes para atenderlos con la amabilidad que la caracteriza. 

Con este crédito de S/.800, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará arroz, azúcar en saco, aceite en galón, gaseosas de diferentes marcas tamaños y sabores, y otros ingredientes que necesita para la preparación diaria de los platos que oferta a sus clientes como verduras, carnes (de res, cerdo, pollo y pescado). Desea tener todo listo para esperar las fiestas patronales de su distrito donde está asegurada sus ventas.

La señora Palmira tiene 41 años de edad, vive con hijo quien aún está estudiando. Es una mujer decidida, alegre y muy perseverante y tiene como meta implementar su negocio con la venta de bebidas.
texts.en:
Palmira belongs to the Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria interim credit group, and lives in the Tarapota district of San Martín province and region. She has a small restaurant located in her home at 203 Elías Aguirre Jirón, a place where she serves her customers with characteristic kindness. With this six-month loan of $275 (800 nuevos soles), Palmira will purchase rice, sugar by the sack, oil by the gallon, soft drinks in various sizes and flavors, and other ingredients needed for the daily preparation of the meals that she offers to her customers—vegetables and meat (beef, pork, chicken and fish). Palmira wishes to have everything ready for her district’s festivals in honor of patron saints, when she will be assured of having sales. Palmira is 41 years old, and lives with her son who is still in school. She is a determined woman, cheerful and very persevering. Her goal for her shop is to branch out into the sale of beverages.

Translated from Spanish by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice, sugar, oil, soft drinks, et cetera

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa A., a widow with five dependents, received schooling through Junior High and has sold gari, beans and corn at Kormantse near Cape Coast since early 2008. Theresa uses her income to pay for food, utility bills and the children's school fees.

Theresa is requesting a loan to purchase more food items for resale. She plans to reinvest the new profits into her growing business and her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase more food items for resale.

loans.name: Oun

texts.en: Mrs. Oun S., 34, earns income selling various kinds of vegetables at a market, and selling porridge in the morning to the people in the area. She can typically make around US$5 per day, while her husband, working as a taxi-driver, earns about US$8 per day. In a typical month, Oun S.'s family spends US$40 on food and US$6 on utilities. For business purposes, S. uses a bicycle to transport the vegetables and other items to and from the market. At present, S. needs a loan to be able to purchase a motor-bike that could make her business more successful and would make her daily commute easier.

loans.use: Purchase of a motor-bike for a business

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina M. M. is 58 years old.  She lives in Pucallpa, Peru – a major city in the eastern jungle region of the country.  This steaming, humid city is situated on the banks of the Ucayali River, a tributary of the Amazon River.  

Gina is a member of the Las Dalilas communal bank and has been taking out small business loans for 1.25 years to support her bodega, or corner store.  These small businesses are very common throughout Peru and provide a convenient way for people to earn livings working from their own homes.  Bodegas are usually located in the converted front room of the home and sales are made through grated windows or doors.  Gina's husband is a farmer and together they support their four children.

Gina is currently requesting a Kiva loan of 1,000 Nuevo Soles to stock her store with vegetables, eggs, rice, beer and bottled drinks.  She will repay the loan in monthly installments.

loans.use: To stock her store with vegetables, eggs, rice, beer and bottled drinks

loans.name: Graciela Maria

texts.es:
Graciela es socia del Bancomunal Las orquídeas.
Graciela es conviviente, tuvo dos hijos, que lamentablemente murieron.
Graciela  estudió contabilidad, cuando empezó a trabajar, fue acosada por su jefe, renunciando, siempre le pasaba lo mismo en los trabajos que conseguía. Entonces decidió poner una tienda de abarrotes, todo iba bien hasta que la asaltaron, llevándose todo,  y quedándose sin capital de trabajo, se dedico a dar desayuno, se levanta a las tres de la madrugada, junto con su esposo,  para la preparación, de la quinua, el quaquer, los samwish, venden en San Juan, desde hace siete años, ahora tienen tres carretas y una persona mas que le ayuda. 
Desde que esta en Finca su vida mejoro, aprendió hacer responsable con sus pagos, siempre a ganado premios por puntualidad, ha hecho buenas amistades. 
Necesita un crédito de 1000 soles, para la compra de ingredientes para dar desayuno,  
El sueño de Graciela es tener un restaurante, viajar a Italia para pasear.
texts.en:
Graciela is an associate of Bancomunal Las Orchídeas. Graciela is a live-in partner, and had two kids who regrettably died. Graciela studied accounting and began working. However each time she would get a job, she was sexually harassed by her bosses, and would have to quit. So she decided to start a grocery store, and everything was going well until she was robbed. They took everything, and left her without any money. She then began to sell breakfast. Now Graciela wakes up at three every morning, together with her husband, to prepare of quinoa, oatmeal, and sandwiches. They have sold these products for seven years, and now they have three wagons and one more person that helps them. Since she has been in Finca her life has improved. She learned to be responsible in making her payments, always winning prizes for her punctuality, making good friendships at the same time. She needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy ingredients so that she can supply her breakfasts. Gracielas dream is to have a restaurant, and to backpack Italy.

Translated from Spanish by Matt Capetola, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Needs a loan of 1000 soles so that she may buy ingredients for the breakfast she sells.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie A. earns a living growing rice. She has been planting rice since she was a child. Because her parents are farmers, she is highly experienced in planting the seeds and harvesting the grains.

Rose is 48 years old. She has 9 children. She has a strong desire to help her husband support their family, so she also sells sampaguita in the nearby barrio. Rose is happy in her marriage. She will do her best to sustain her family.

Rose needs a loan of Php 10,000. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers. Specifically, she will use the loan to buy 2 bags of urea and triple 14. She will also seek out other income-generating projects to augment their limited income.

Joining the CEVI credit program gave Rosemarie access to the credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage that CEVI gives.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Clemantine

texts.fr: Clemantine S. est une jeune femme de 32 ans, mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle est détentrice d’une boutique d’alimentation générale au centre ville d’Atakpamé, une ville située à environ 150 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Elle exerce cette activité depuis 5 ans. Elle espère avec ce crédit accroître la taille de son commerce en approvisionnant sa boutique de nouveaux produits. Dans la vue, elle est avec son mari.
texts.en:
Clemantine S., age 32, is married and the mother of two children. She owns a grocery store in the center of Atakpamé, a city located approximately 150 kilometers from Lomé, the capital of Togo. She's been running this business for five years. With this loan, she hopes to expand her business by supplying her store with new products. In the photograph, she's with her husband.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To supply her grocery store

loans.name: Siguidia (Fait Bon Vivre) Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq femmes du groupe Siguidia sont toutes mariées, la moyenne d’âge des femmes du groupe se situe autour de 27 ans  et elles ont en moyenne  4 enfants. Les membres du groupe Siguidia vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Dalan de la ville de San (région de Ségou, république du Mali). 
Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage et de parenté.
Elles exercent  la même activité de vente  de manioc frais et de poissons fumés. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité.
 Pour satisfaire  le  besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Siguidia a  eu une solution à ses problèmes en intégrant  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son premier  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). 
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des cartons  de poissons fumés à Mopti et à Korientzé, quant au manioc il  est acheté au fur  et à mesure auprès des producteurs. Le poisson est vendu au comptant, en détail à la maison et dans les marchés environnants de San. Quant au manioc, il est vendu  au marché de San  à la maison et en ambulant, au comptant, en détail et à crédit. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 65 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five women in the Siguidia group are all married; they have an average age of about 27 and they have an average of four children each. The Siguidia group members live in traditional large extended families in the Dalan neighborhood of San (a town in the Ségou region of the Republic of Mali). They got to know each other through neighborhood and family connections. They all perform the same business activity selling fresh manioc and smoked fish. They are very much in demand in this business. In order to satisfy the needs of their ever-increasing clientele, the Siguidia group found a solution to their problems by joining the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution with whom they are requesting their first group loan. They intend to use this loan to buy boxes of smoked fish in Mopti and Korientzé. As for the manioc, it is purchased as and when from the growers. The fish are sold separately for cash from home and in the markets around San. As for the manioc, it is sold retail at the San market, from home and door-to-door for cash or credit. During this loan cycle, each member of the group expects to make an average profit of 65,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay the loan interest, provide for the needs of the extended family and the remainder will be invested in the business.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy smoked fish and manioc

loans.name: Lien's Group

texts.en:
Liên Lê Thị was born in 1958. She lives in Xuan Trach Villarge. Her main job is farming. Every day, she receives paper to make pockets. Presently, she lives with her husband, her mother-in-law and three children. Her family has a monthly income of about $190. She wants to borrow $356. She is a group leader. There are five other loan participants in her group .
 Hằng Hoàng Thị was born in 1981.  She wants to borrow $282 to buy scrap paper to make pockets.
 Thuyên Lê Thị was born in 1966. She wants to borrow $282 to repair her house. 
 Xuân Lê Thị was born in 1954. She wants to borrow $233 to buy food for pigs.
 Xiêm Nguyễn Thị was born in 1966. She wants to borrow $110 to buy eggs to resell in the market.
 Thu Lê Thị was born in 1963. She wants to borrow $233 to buy pigs and food for them.

loans.use: To buy pigs, eggs and scrap paper.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es: Elizabet tiene 32 años, es una madre muy luchadora y responsable, vive en su propia casa junto a sus queridos hijos Néstor de 9 y Karen de 4 meses, desea darles unos buenos estudios, motivo por el cual está dispuesta a trabajar duramente. La compra, crianza y venta de cerdos es el negocio que realiza Elizabeth diariamente, sus cerdos son muy solicitados en las ferias, ya que siempre están bien alimentados y son muy grandes. Todos los días muy temprano por la mañana se levanta para darle a sus cerdos el alimento que necesitan para crecer, los cuida con mucho cariño, puesto que sabe que gracias a ellos tendrá el dinero para mantener a su familia. Los 5 años que lleva en este negocio le han dado la experiencia necesaria para realizar un buen trabajo, lo que más le gusta es que al mismo tiempo puede realizar sus labores hogareñas y velar por sus cerdos. Espera más adelante incrementar el número de porcinos que cría, lo más difícil de su trabajo es evitar que sus animales se vayan lejos y se pierdan, sobre todo tiene mucho cuidado con su engreído el chanchito “Bartolomeo” con quien quiso tomarse la foto. Este es tercer préstamo de Elizabet en MFP, en sus anteriores créditos ha sido muy puntual y espera serlo ahora también, en su banco comunal es una socia muy respetada, debido a la responsabilidad que demuestra. Con los mil ochocientos soles comprará más comida para sus cerdos, también aprovechará para comprar otros dos.
texts.en:
Elizabeth is 32 years old and a spirited, responsible mother. She lives in her own home with her dear children, 9-year-old Néstor and 4-month-old Karen. She is willing to work hard to give them a good education.
Elizabeth makes a living purchasing, raising and selling pigs. Her pigs are in high demand in the markets since they are always very big and well-fed. She gets up early every day to feed her pigs what they need to grow. She looks after them with much affection since she knows that thanks to them she’ll have money to support her family. Her 5 years in this business have given her the necessary experience to do her job well.
What she most likes about her work is being able to look after her household while watching over the pigs. In the future, she hopes to raise a larger number of pigs. The most difficult part of her job is keeping her animals from straying too far and getting lost. She especially takes care of her piggy Bartolomeo, who is with her in the photo.
This is Elizabeth’s third loan with MFP; she has made punctual repayments in the past and hopes to continue doing so. She is a well-respected, responsible member of her communal bank. She will purchase more pig feed and two more pigs with the 1800 soles.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase two pigs and pig feed

loans.name: Shamim Akhtar Muhammad Akram Group

texts.en:
Shamim Akhtar Baji is a widow residing in the historical site of Yadgar in Lahore, Pakistan. Her husband died 3 years ago from an accident. Shamim Baji never loses her courage and fights with her circumstances. She started a clothes selling business. She chose this business because she knows that in Lahore people are fond of clothes. Through this business, she is able to pay her utilities easily. Nowadays, she is out of stock but she has a good number of orders. So she is applying for a loan to buy more clothes to complete the orders of her customers.
Nasreen Baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business.
Naseem Akhtar Baji wants a loan to buy cigarette packets to sell. The picture belongs to Naseem Akhtar Baji who is showing her cigarette packets. 
This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Jose Reynaldo

texts.es: El señor José Reynaldo S. Meléndez, tiene la edad de 61 años, habita en el Reparto Juan Ramón Padilla, junto a su esposa, la cual le apoya con los gastos del hogar, ellos tiene tres hijos, todos mayor de edad independientes, los planes hacia su familia es mejorar las condiciones de vida, desde hace cinco años don Reynaldo trabaja como chofer, su sueños es poder terminar de construir su casa, ya que el necesita un financiamiento para poder realizar sus sueños.  Con el préstamo va a comprar materiales de construcción para hacer las paredes de concreto y poder tener mejor seguridad para su familia.
texts.en:
José Reynaldo S. Meléndez is 61 years old. He lives in the Juan Ramón Padilla neighborhood with his wife, who helps him cover living expenses. They have three children, all of them adults. His plan for his family is to improve their living conditions. Don Reynaldo has been working as a driver for five years. He hopes to finish building his house, and needs financing to be able to make that dream come true. He will use the loan to purchase construction materials for the concrete walls and make his family more secure.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials for concrete walls

loans.name: Kwadwo

texts.en:
Kwadwo M. is forty-six years old. He is married and has five children, all of whom are still school. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Suhum, in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Kwadwo works hard to be able to provide for his family.

He runs a drug store in his community, selling all kinds of tablets and syrups. His shop is located by the road side. Kwadwo procures his drugs from big pharmacy shops in the cities. He has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to buy drugs in bulk to increase his stock. He aspires to sponsor all his children in school to the higher levels.

loans.use: To buy drugs in bulk for his pharmacy.

loans.name: Melocoton Group

texts.es:
Foto de Izquierda a derecha: Odaly Isabel Sánchez, Darling Lizeth O. H. y Damaris de los Angeles A. Mejía.

Este grupo es originario de la a ciudad de Masaya, de forma general se dedican a las actividades de ventas.
Son bien conocidas entre ellas y de confianza, son mujeres jóvenes que tienen mucho empeño y trabajar y salir adelante, les gusta trabajar con Adim porque reciben capacitaciones de cómo mejorar su negocio.
Doña Odaly Isabel Sánchez ,vende ropa y cosméticos a personas de la comunidad, es madre de dos niños de 5 y 10 años, desea poder sacar adelante a sus hijos, este estudia en la escuela cercana a la vivienda, es casada, su esposo es panadero y le apoya con los gastos del hogar. El crédito lo ocupa para comprar ropa que le encargan sus clientes, además ella hace buñuelos para vender por las tardes.

Doña Darling Lizeth O. es la coordinadora del grupo, ella anima al grupo a quedar bien y seguir obteniendo los beneficios del crédito con Adim. Es una mujer joven sin hijos, su negocio para tener más ingresos para ayudar con los gastos, su esposo trabaja como chofer de taxi. Ella vende atoles, tamales, tortillas, los vende en punto fijo donde pasa mucha gente que ya la conoce.


Doña Damaris de los Angeles A. ,  es una  mujer, madre de varios hijos que ahora ya no viven con ella, ella se dedica a la elaboración de pantalones, camisas y faldas, tiene su pequeño taller en su casa, cuenta con dos trabajadoras, ella sale a vender a los departamentos como Matagalpa, Estela y Rivas. El credito lo necesita para la compra de materiales en el mercado como telas. hilos, adornos, etc., tiene muchos clientes que le piden encargos, sueña con tener su propia vivienda, ella es muy responsable.

 Expresa que en cada crédito ella se propone metas para salir adelante.
texts.en:
In the photo from left to right: Odaly, Darling, and Damaris.

This group is from the city of Masaya and they all sell products.

They know each other well and trust each other,and each is a young woman with determination and a good work ethic. They like to work with ADIM because they receive training on how to improve their businesses.

Odaly sells clothing and cosmetics to people in the community. She is the mother of two children, one five and the other ten, and hopes that they can continue moving forward with their studies at the school near her house. She is married and her husband, who is a baker, helps her with household expenses. The loan she requests will go towards the purchase of clothing that her customers have ordered. She also makes doughnuts to sell in the afternoons.

Darling is the captain of the group and encourages the group to keep making a good impression so that they can keep receiving loans with ADIM. She is a young woman without children and has a business in order to bring in income and help with expenses. Her husband works as a taxi driver. She sells maize drinks, tamales, and tortillas in a regular spot where many people that know her pass.

Damaris is a mother of several children that no longer live with her. She makes pants, shirts, and skirts and has a small workshop in her house for her and two workers. She leaves to sell her products in Matagalpa, Estela and Rivas. The loan that she requests is to purchase materials in the market like fabrics, thread, decorations, etc. She has many customers that have special orders. Her dream is to have her own house and she is very responsible.

She says that with each loan she proposes goals to keep moving forward.

Translated from Spanish by Laurie Paguio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase materials for food and clothing sales

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
In Barangay Manamtam of Bambang Nueva Vizcaya, Milagros and Benny V. live harmoniously with their four children. Their children are students at the high school and elementary school level. The couple would like to further expand their vending business so that they can continue to send their children to school.

Milagros is pleased and happy because, as a result of the income she has generated from her business, she assists her husband in paying their living expenses. She sells different kind of vegetables in their village. More specifically, she buys vegetables at wholesale prices at the Nueva Vizcaya Agricultural Terminal (NVAT), where many vegetables are sold to retail customers. Unfortunately, she has limited capital. So, to improve her vending business, she is seeking a loan in the amount of $275 (12,000 PHP) from Kiva lenders. She hopes that lenders will grant her loan request so that her business will continue to grow and become sustainable over time.

loans.use: For general capital needs and to expand and improve the business

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel L. manages a community-based store in her village at General Balao of Solana, Cagayan. She is an energetic woman, untiringly maintaining her business, keeping household chores and taking care of her children. She started her store in 1995. She purchases her products in the big grocery store in the town proper of Solana. 

She wishes to obtain a loan from Kiva amounting to PHP 6,000 as additional capital in order to improve her store and keep up with her business' competitors. Maribel is also happy that her husband, Domingo, is helping her to manage the business. Their five children are their inspiration, to work harder to give the children a bright future.

loans.use: To improve her store and keep up with competitors

loans.name: Akinwade

texts.en:
Akinwade sells charcoal. She is 35 years old and married with three children. She has been in the business for a long time.

Akinwade has finished repaying her first loan and is grateful to all the lenders for the support they gave to her. She is requesting a new loan of N80,000 to purchase more charcoal to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: Moses is twenty nine years old. He is married and has two children who are in school. Moses is an auto mechanic and a retailer of engine oil, brake fluid, gaskets and other car spare parts. He buys his supplies from oil filling station operators in barrels and sells in smaller quantities to his customers. Moses is handicapped by low working capital since oil prices have gone up. He therefore needs a loan to remain in business. He wants to use the loan to buy additional barrels of engine oil, gallons of brake fluid and spare parts to serve his customers. Moses believes this will enable him to make a good income from his business. He would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy additional barrels of engine oil, gaskets, bolts and knots, gallons of oil brake fluid and spare parts

loans.name: Luzel

texts.en:
Luzel T. is from the village of Poblacion Ramon Magsaysay, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 37 years old. Luzel is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Luzel owns & operates a "calenderia," a mini restaurant. The main source of income for the business comes from serving a variety of different meals to customers, and different products to sell in the local community. Luzel has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2008, Luzel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luzel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to expand the business. Luzel is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase foods & drinks for the mini restaurant. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Luzel from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food & drinks for the mini restaurant

loans.name: Silvia

texts.es:
Silvia tiene 30 años, trabaja muy duramente, pues sus deseos son de velar por el bienestar  de su hogar. Ella sola trata de cubrir los gastos de sus 2 hijos, con quienes vive en su pequeña casa que apenas está en construcción.

La habilidad que tiene en las máquinas de coser le abrió las puertas para trabajar en diversos talleres textiles de su distrito y ahora viene trabajando en sociedad con su hermana, y ambas trabajan reciben pedidos de las fábricas del centro de la ciudad.
Ella considera que la rentabilidad de su negocio se encuentra en la fabricación de diseños nuevos para después ofrecerlos a los fabricantes, pues reciben ingresos adicionales por los diseños y la elaboración. En estos 5 años de labor ha podido disfrutar diseñando diversas prendas, sin embargo lo difícil de su trabajo es hacer los acabados, pues son cientos de prendas y esto le afecta la vista.
Para el futuro, Silvia planeado instalar un taller con maquinaria nueva que agilicen su trabajo en casa.

Este es su primer préstamo con Microfinanzas PRISMA, por lo que se compromete a trabajar arduamente para no defraudar la confianza que depositaron en ella y en su trabajo. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprara los materiales de costura necesarios para seguir trabajando y entregando sus pedidos con prontitud.
texts.en:
Silvia is 30 years old and works very hard, striving to ensure the well-being of her household. She alone tries to cover the expenses of her two children; she lives with them in a small house which is still under construction. Her talent with sewing machines opened the doors for her to work in various textile workshops of her district. Now she is working in partnership with her sister; both of them receive and fill orders from factories in the city center. Silvia believes that the profitability of her business depends on producing new designs to offer to the manufacturers, since she and her sister receive additional income for their designs and creations. During the past 5 years in her business, she has enjoyed the process of designing a range of clothing items. However, the most difficult part of her job is the finishing work, since there are hundreds of garments and the work affects her eyesight. For the future, Silvia plans to install a workshop with new machines which will make her work at home easier. This is Silvia's first loan with PRISMA Microfinances, and she has made a commitment to work hard and not to abuse the confidence that has been placed in her and her work. With the funds she is requesting, she will purchase the necessary sewing supplies so that she can continue working and delivering her orders promptly.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing textile supplies

loans.name: Las Golondrinas Group

texts.es: El grupo "Las Golondrinas" esta represen por la señora Fatima  y conformada por 12 miembros que cursan su primer ciclo a pesar D. ello ya cuentan con experiencia en grupos solidarios ya que trabajaron antes en un grupo anterior por lo que decidieron conformar un grupo nuevo y renovado. Sus integrantes tienen su negocio como la venta comida, ropa, servicio mecánico, D. transporte público y a la producción y elaboración D. pan. El comercio en este grupo es muy variado, su nivel D. ventas es muy bueno, teniendo buena rentabilidad y capacidad D. pago a pesar D. existir bastante competencia.  El crédito esta destinado al incremento D. su capital, esperan mejorar sus ventas  y el crédito será invertido en la compra D. más mercadería que será utilizado para generar mayores ganancia para poder otorgarles a sus familias una mejor calidad D. vida y un futuro mas prometedor a sus hijos que son su razón para seguir adelante. En cuanto a la experiencia crediticia los socios ya trabajaron atentes en instituciones financieras similares a la Fundación Agrocapital a la que están muy agradecidos por la confianza y el apoyo económico brindado.
texts.en:
The "Las Golondrinas" (The Swallows) group is maD. up of 12 members who are in their first loan cycle although they have worked with communal groups before and decided to form a new, renewed group; they are led by Fatima. The members are involved in various commercial activities like: food and clothing sales, bread baking, public transportation, vehicle repairs. Their commerce is varied, has good sales, good profits, and good ability to repay despite heavy competition. The financing will be used to increase working capital; they hope to improve sales and the funds will be used to buy more merchandise which will be used to generate higher profits to be able to proviD. their families with a better quality of life and a more promissing future for their children, who are their main reason to continue forward. With regard to credit history, they have worked previously with financial institutions similar to Fundación Agrocapital and they are grateful to it for the confidence and economic help granted.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia J. is currently in the business of selling beer and local alcohol and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell. Lucia is 35 years old and is married to a peasant. She has 6 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar in the market.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer to sell.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en: Flora G. is from the village of Laturan Libona Bukidnon. She is 43 years old. Flora is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Flora owns, operates a business venture in the food sector making, and selling food as well in service sector.  The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling specialty food products like viands and rice, she also accept t-shirts printing in the local community. Flora has been apart of her business for over 15 years.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Ape

texts.en:
Ape S. is 59 and married with 7 children (ages 9 - 25).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Ape has 1 year of experience in this business.  Ape needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to financially support immediate members of her family.

In 2009, Ape rejoined the SPBD program so that she can financially support her business in regards of her request for a small loan. This is her 1st loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Ape's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

Overall Social Metric Score:*                1.6 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15"

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Reyna Teresa

texts.es: La señora Teresa tiene 32 años de edad, se caso joven y procreo tres hijos el mayor tiene 11,8 y 4 años de edad, estudiantes de la primaria, su esposo de oficio mecánico pero también esta trabajando como guarda de seguridad en el barrio en las noches debido ala delincuencia que se ha incrementado y a si gana otro dinero extra y poder cubrir junto con su esposa los gastos. Doña Teresa se dedica ala venta de carne de res y de cerdo ella reside en un barrio de Santa Elena carretera norte, en donde le queda cerca el carnit que se le hace mas cerca para comprar la carne, mas barata y de buena calidad, tiene tres años de estar con sus ventas, las dificultades que se le presenta es cuando un niño se le enferma toma parte del capital con que trabaja y queda con poco, para comprar la carne. Y lo que mas desea es poder invertir en más para mejorar su inventario  y obtener mejores ganancias. Con este préstamo comprara mucho más carne, un cerdo y sacos de maíz para comenzar  a palmear tortilla ya que desea ahorrar para poder hacer su casa en mejores condiciones ya que es insegura y forrada de zinc con tabla, y de tierra lo cual espera pronto poder a mejorarla para una mejor comodidad como higiene de su familia.
texts.en:
Ms. Teresa is 32 years old; she married young. She has three children of 11, 8 and 4 years of age, all students in elementary school. Her husband is a mechanic but is also working as a security guard in the neighborhood at night due to the increase in the crime rate; this way he earns some extra money to be able to cover the expenses with his wife. Ms. Teresa is dedicated to the sale of beef and pork. She lives in the Santa Elena neighborhood in the northern highway, where she lives close to a butcher where she buys good quality meat at lower prices. She has been selling for over 3 years. She has had to endure some hardship when a child gets ill and she uses up part of her capital and ends up having less funds to purchase meat. She wishes to be able to invest in inventory and earn more money. With this loan she will purchase more meat, a pig and sacks of corn to be able to make tortillas since she wishes to save some money to be able to improve the quality of her home since it is not safe, just covered in zinc, planks and earth, so she is hoping that she will be able to live more comfortably and to improve the hygiene of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Esteban Riojas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase meat, a pig and sacks of corn

loans.name: Warlito

texts.en:
Warlito tills 2 hectares of rice field. He has been doing this since he was younger. He is now 33 years old. He keeps himself away from sickness so that he can always attend to the farm he tills. He is always determined to have an abundant harvest. Despite having experienced failure in harvest, he still works hard to achieve what he wants. 

He applied for a loan of 14,000 Philippine pesos from CEVI, a Kiva partner. He said that he would use the loan to buy farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers. He likes CEVI’s low interest rate.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Umedchon

texts.ru: Шарипов Умедчон проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 34 года. Женат, имеет 9 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Он живет вместе с родителями. У них большая семья. Его родители пенсионеры. Сам Умедчон занимается растениеводством. Он более 8 лет выращивает пшеницу, оващи и вывозит на рынок. Кредит просит для закупа минеральных удобрений. Умедчон намерен посеить пшеницу и получить хороший урожай для продажи. Таким способом он получит большую прибыль и расширит свой бизнес.
texts.en:
Umedchon S. lives in the Hamadoni district. He is 34 years old, married and has 9 children. His wife is a homemaker. He lives together with his parents, who are retired. They have a big family. Umedchon is involved in agriculture. He has been growing wheat and vegetables and selling the crops at the market. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of mineral fertilizers. Umedchon intends to plant wheat and gather a good harvest for sale. This way he will make a big profit and expand his business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Abir

texts.en: Abir is a 37-year-old married woman with two unemployed children. Since 2005, she has owned and operated a shop that sells clothes and shoes. Before opening her own store, she worked in another shop for ten years. Abir is requesting a loan for $1,200 so she can expand her inventory and offer the new season's clothes and shoes to her clients. This will help her business create more profits. Abir loves being able to offer support to her family from her earnings.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory for clothing sales

loans.name: Rolando

texts.es:
EL SEÑOR ROLANDO SE DEDICA A LA ACTIVIDAD DE TRANSPORTE URBANO DE PASAJEROS, EL COMENZO CON ESTE ACTIVIDADPORQUE NO ENCONTRABA TRABAJO CON EL RUBRO DE SUS ESTUDIOS QUE ES MUY COMUN EN BOLIVIA QUE PERSONAS PROFESIONALES POR LA FALTA DE EMPLEO SE DEDIQUEN A SER CHOFERES, SACO UN PRESTAMO DEL BANCO PARA COMPRAR UNA MOVILIDAD Y ASI TENER ESTOS INGRESOS YA QUE EL NO PUDO SOLO VER QUE SUS PAPAS LE DEN DINERO ACTUALMENTE ESTA TRABAJANDO DE CHOFER QUE TRABAJA DESDE TEMPRANAS HORAS DEL DIA HASTA ALTAS HORAS DE LA NOCHE, AHORA EL SE ENCUENTRA  MUY FELIZ CON SU MOVILIDAD YA QUE CONOCE A NUEVAS PERSONAS Y TIENE MUCHOS CLIENTES Y NO TIENE QUE PREOCUPARSE PARA LLEVAR EL PAN DE CADA DIA A SU HOGAR. CON EL DINERO DEL CREDITO REALIZARA EL MANTENIMIENTO DE SU VEHICULO.
ES UN JOVEN MUY TRABAJADOR Y ESTA AGRADECIDO CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Rolando provides urban public transportation services. He went into this line of work because he couldn’t find employment in his chosen career. It is very common in Bolivia for professional people, who can’t find work, to become drivers. He took out a bank loan to buy his vehicle in order to have a source of income so as not to depend on his parents for money any longer. He works as a driver from very early in the morning until very late at night. He is happy with his vehicle because he gets to meet new people and he has many customers so he does not have to worry about earning his daily income. He will use the requested funds for vehicle maintenance and repair. He is a very hard-working young man and he’s grateful to Emprender and to Kiva for the trust placed in him by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For vehicle maintenance and repair.

loans.name: Riverlee Sisters Group

texts.en:
Decontee M. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'Riverlee Sisters'. She is 49 years old, married, and has five children ranging in age from 7 to 32.  She could not continue her education past 7th grade due to financial problems.

For 20 years, Decontee has been selling soft drinks at the Riverlee Cinema on Broad Street, downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She approaches her customers in a nice manner which keeps customers returning. But she has a problem with carrying soft drinks to the Ministry of Finance right opposite where she also sells because she has to climb stairs to get to customers.

Decontee started by selling peanuts. She plans to use her portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to purchase more soft drinks to improve her business.  And her hopes and dreams are to send her children to school and build a house for her family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Decontee is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more soft drinks to improve her business

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica M., 33, is a hardworking businesswoman. She is married with three children schooling and she also has two other dependents who are in school. She has a grocery business that she's been in for over nine years. She is using the loan to purchase sugar, drinks, salt and so forth. Her dream is to expand her business for better profits.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, drinks, salt and so forth

loans.name: Brigida

texts.es: LA SRA. BRIGIDA ES UNA PERSONA MUY TRABAJADORA Y ALEGRE, ELLA ADMINISTRA SU MINIBUS DE SIETE PASAJEROS EL CUAL FUE INGRESADO EN EL SINDICATO DE TRANSPORTES MIRAFLORES. SU ESPOSO ORLANDO ES TECNICO EN SERIGRAFIA EN UNA PEQUEÑA EMPRESA. ELLOS VIVEN EN LA ZONA DE BAJO PAMPAHASI QUE SE ENCUENTRA A 30 MINUTOS DEL CENTRO DE LA CUIDAD. TIENEN DOS PEQUEÑOS HIJOS EN EDAD ESCOLAR. BRIGIDA  JUNTO  A SU ESPOSO HAN DECIDIDO COMENZAR SU PROPIA EMPRESA DE SERIGRAFIADOS YA QUE ORLANDO TIENE MUCHA EXPERIENCIA EN ESTA ACTIVIDAD. ELLOS REALIZAN TRABAJOS DE FABRICACION DE LETREROS, LUMINARIAS, LLAVEROS Y ESTAMPADOS ENTRE OTROS. BRIGIDA TRABAJA CON NUESTRA INSTITUCION DESDE HACE VARIOS AÑOS Y EN ESTE TIEMPO HA DEMOSTRADO SER UNA PERSONA RESPONSABLE Y TRABAJADORA, CON EL DINERO DEL CREDITO COMPRARA UNA COMPUTADORA PARA EL USO EN TRABAJOS DE LA IMPRENTA, ESTA MUY AGRADECIDA CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO .
texts.en:
Brigida is a hard-working and cheerful person who runs a seven-passenger minibus service, which is part of the transport system in Miraflores, Bolivia. Her husband Orlando is a print technician in a small business. They live thirty minutes from the center of town and have two school-age children. Brigida and her husband have decided to start their own printing business to capitalize on his vast experience. They will make signboards, lighted signs, keyrings and other stamped products. Brigida has worked with Emprender for many years and has always been responsible and hard-working. She will use the loan to buy a computer for their printing business. She thanks Emprender and Kiva for their support.

Translated from Spanish by Ross Forman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a computer

loans.name: Maiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Maiya L. lives in Khokhana-Dobato, Lalitpur. She is married and has a son and a daughter. Her son is studying in grade 11 and daughter in grade 7.

She is a farmer in Khokhana-Dobato and grows different types of vegetables. Due to the lack of technology most of the farmers in this area depend on seasonal farming.

Mrs. L. sells her vegetables in the local vegetable market in the mornings and evenings. Now she is requesting a loan to buy seeds and fertilizers for her work.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Alicia Raquel

texts.es:
Alicia es socia del Banco Comunal Imasumacc que significa Que Bello en quechua y los que mas le gusta son las capacitaciones.
Alicia es casada y tiene 3 hijos, tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, bebidas, golosinas, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda eventual de sus hijos. Su préstamo será destinado para la compra de azúcar, arroz y leche.
Alicia sueña con que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Alicia is a member of the Imasumacc Communal Bank which means How Beautiful in Quechua and what she likes most are trainings. Alicia is married and has three children. She runs a store out of her home where she sells groceries including drinks and sweets. She works seven days a week with occasional help from her children. Her loan will be used to purchase sugar, rice and milk. Alicia dreams that some day her children will be professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Margaret Wolfe-Roberts, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sugar, rice and milk.

loans.name: Roniel

texts.en:
Roniel T. is from the village of  Iligan City. He is 23 years old. Roniel is single. To make a living, Roniel owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorcycle  services to local community members. Roniel has been engaged in his business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Roniel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Roniel is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Roniel from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide transportation services
